body:
**Kubernetes version** (use `kubectl version`):
```
$kubectl version
Client Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"5", GitVersion:"v1.5.1", GitCommit:"82450d03cb057bab0950214ef122b67c83fb11df", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2016-12-14T00:57:05Z", GoVersion:"go1.7.4", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"darwin/amd64"}
Server Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"5", GitVersion:"v1.5.1+coreos.0", GitCommit:"cc65f5321f9230bf9a3fa171155c1213d6e3480e", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2016-12-14T04:08:28Z", GoVersion:"go1.7.4", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}
```

**Environment**:
- **Cloud provider or hardware configuration**: AWS
- **OS** (e.g. from /etc/os-release): CoreOS


**What happened**:
Running through the following example (http://kubernetes.io/docs/admin/kube-scheduler/) you cannot start a second scheduler without disabling leader-elect if the default scheduler has leader-elect enabled (default). I think the lock needs to configurable based on scheduler name.


**What you expected to happen**:
You can run subsequent schedulers with leader-elect using a separate lock.


**How to reproduce it** (as minimally and precisely as possible):
Run through -- http://kubernetes.io/docs/admin/kube-scheduler/

Yields
```
$ kubectl logs my-scheduler-3263660448-r8xfq   -n kube-system -f
W1220 18:09:43.712076       1 client_config.go:481] Neither --kubeconfig nor --master was specified.  Using the inClusterConfig.  This might not work.
I1220 18:09:43.760718       1 leaderelection.go:247] lock is held by ip-10-0-10-11.us-west-2.compute.internal and has not yet expired
I1220 18:09:47.214644       1 leaderelection.go:247] lock is held by ip-10-0-10-11.us-west-2.compute.internal and has not yet expired
I1220 18:09:49.939585       1 leaderelection.go:247] lock is held by ip-10-0-10-11.us-west-2.compute.internal and has not yet expired
I1220 18:09:53.178888       1 leaderelection.go:247] lock is held by ip-10-0-10-11.us-west-2.compute.internal and has not yet expired
```

Adding leader-elect=false to subsequent kube-scheduler gets round this at the moment
```
$kubectl logs my-scheduler-3263660448-wr6bc   -n kube-system -fem
W1220 18:11:13.475504       1 client_config.go:481] Neither --kubeconfig nor --master was specified.  Using the inClusterConfig.  This might not work.
I1220 18:11:13.519262       1 event.go:217] Event(api.ObjectReference{Kind:"Pod", Namespace:"default", Name:"annotation-second-scheduler", UID:"28908cea-c6df-11e6-b886-06f3d2138bbf", APIVersion:"v1", ResourceVersion:"977630", FieldPath:""}): type: 'Warning' reason: 'FailedScheduling' no nodes available to schedule pods
```

**Anything else do we need to know**:

labels.description: Categorizes an issue or PR as relevant to SIG Scheduling.
labels.name: sig/scheduling

title: Running multiple-schedulers with leader-elect
